text: [Music]
I've always been interested as a
sociologist and a researcher and trying
to understand better how issues related
to race and gender inequality persists
in professional workplaces and I think
that's because particularly when we
think about the ways that the economy
has changed and work has changed
especially over the last 30 or 40 years
there's a real widening gap between what
sociologists aren't in kallenberg refers
to as good jobs and bad jobs and the
good jobs are those that offer benefits
more stability more comfortable wages
more options for upward mobility and
more Status bad jobs would be those jobs
that don't do that but I think that even
as there's a shrinking proportion of
good jobs and a recognition that those
good jobs are one of the few
opportunities for mobility and economic
stability and comfort there's also been
a sense that for black Americans their
experiences are either this constant
drumbeat of discrimination even in those
sorts of jobs or that they get into
those jobs and are able to escape the
sort of racial issues that may plague
their work in class or lower caste lower
class counterparts and I don't think
either of those stories is necessarily
true and researching these questions and
topics gives me a way in an opportunity
to delve into them more quickly and get
at the grey area that's between those
two poles I think it's important to
think about these groups who have been
overlooked because they're going to
constitute a bigger and much more
integral part of our workforce going
forward as us demographics begin to
change and the u.s. becomes increasingly
a country where there is no racial
majority group and continues to become
majority minority so a couple of the key
takeaways from my presentation are that
it's critical to be mindful of how race
has an impact and continues to have an
impact on workers from a broad variety
of backgrounds and in a broad variety of
occupations and professions and how we
have to be mindful of the ways in which
those workers may be influenced or
formed by their racial experiences and
ways that have an impact on the work
that they do and how they approach their
jobs and the types of requirements that
are expected from them when they go to
work and I think that being more mindful
of the ways in which our work
versus becoming more racially diverse is
only beneficial to organizations and
companies because it enables them to be
more mindful of the broad talent pool
that's available to them and to
reconstruct organizations in ways that
are better suited for reaching that
talent pool and allowing everyone's
human capital to show through the reason
I emphasize the persistent problem of
the color line is as a reference to the
insights that sociologists w/e be Du
Bois offered at the turn of the century
where he makes the argument that the
problem of the 20th century will be the
problem of the color line and makes the
series are really well articulated in
very empirically and theoretically
nuanced arguments about the ways that
race continues to matter at that point
in time what's interesting to me now and
in doing research on this topic is that
a lot of the general issues and problems
and disparities that Dubois points to
still remain this is not in any way to
suggest that we haven't made progress
obviously there has been progress over
the course of the 20th century in terms
of addressing race relations and racial
progress but in keeping an eye on that
progress we also have to be mindful of
the way that racial progress in America
takes sort of a two steps forward one
step back patterning which is to say
that whenever there are significant
advancements in racial progress and
racial equity there are always followed
that always is followed by backlash and
that that's been pretty consistent
whether we look at the outcome of the
Civil War and reconstruction and the
backlash that followed that or the
advent of the civil rights movement and
the ways in which forms of platforms and
practices that perpetuate racism simply
shifted practice and form but still
continue to persist and this is why we
can look now and see that recent data
show that if you look over the last 50
years progress for african-americans has
been virtually at a standstill that
increases in home ownership have not
significantly manifested themselves
increases in education have not moved
the needle in a marked fashion we see
over representation in the criminal
justice system again not due to
proclivities of criminal behavior but
due to issues like over policing
which is a result of the presence of
their prison industrial complex so it's
important I think as researchers to be
mindful of how even in the recent
progress of the first black president of
the country was followed by the elect
never president who came to prominence
by doubting the legitimacy in the
citizenship of that first black
president I think it's critical and
necessary to be mindful of how we are
making progress but to also be aware of
how progress doesn't necessarily
indicate equality and that equality
should be our end goal but that we
shouldn't be deterred or just or
discouraged or seduced by the promise of
progress that we have made without
getting to the end goal that we want to
see which is real racial equality
happening
